Simbegwire 
 Rukia Nantale 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When Simbegwire’s mother died, she was 
 
 very sad. Simbegwire's father did his 
 best to take care of his daughter. Slowly, 
 
 they learned to fel hapy again, without 
 Simbegwire's mother. 
 
 
 Every morning they sat and talked about 
 the day ahead. Every evening they made 
 
 diner together. After they washed the 
 dishes, Simbegwire's father helped her 
 with homework. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One day, Simbegwire's father came home
 later than usual. “Where are you my
 
 child?” he caled. 
 
 Simbegwire ran to her father. She
 
 stoped stil when she saw that he was
 holding a woman's hand. "I want you to
 
 met someone special, my child. This is
 Anita," he said smiling. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “Helo Simbegwire, your father told me a 
 lot about you,” said Anita. But she did not 
 
 smile or take the girl's hand. 
 
 Simbegwire's father was hapy and 
 
 excited. He talked about the thre of 
 them living together, and how god their 
 
 life would be. "My child, I hope you wil 
 acept Anita as your mother," he said. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Simbegwire’s life changed. She no longer
 
 had time to sit with her father in the
 mornings. Anita gave her so many
 
 household chores that she was to tired
 to do her schol work in the evenings.
 She went straight to bed after diner.
 
 
 Her only comfort was the colourful
 
 blanket her mother gave her. 
 Simbegwire's father did not sem to
 notice that his daughter was unhapy.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 After a few months, Simbegwire’s father 
 told them that he would be away from 
 
 home for a while. "I have to travel for my 
 job," he said. "But I know you wil lok 
 after each other." 
 
 
 Simbegwire’s face fel, but her father did 
 
 not notice. Anita did not say anything. 
 She was not hapy either. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Things got worse for Simbegwire. If she
 didn't finish her chores, or she
 complained, Anita hit her. And at diner,
 
 the woman ate most of the fod, leaving
 Simbegwire with only a few scraps.
 
 
 Each night Simbegwire cried herself to
 slep, huging her mother’s blanket.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One morning, Simbegwire was late 
 geting out of bed. “You lazy girl!” Anita 
 shouted. She puled Simbegwire out of 
 
 bed. The precious blanket caught on a 
 nail, and tore in two. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Simbegwire was very upset. She decided
 to run away from home. She tok the
 pieces of her mother’s blanket, packed
 
 some fod, and left the house. She
 folowed the road her father had taken.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When it came to evening, she climbed a 
 
 tal tre near a stream and made a bed 
 for herself in the branches. 
 
 
 As she went to slep, she sang: 
 “Mama, mama, mama, you left me. 
 You left me and never came back. 
 
 Father doesn’t love me anymore. 
 Mother, when are you coming back? 
 
 You left me.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The next morning, Simbegwire sang the
 
 song again. When the women came to
 wash their clothes at the stream, they
 heard the sad song coming from the tal
 
 tre. 
 
 They thought it was only the wind
 
 rustling the leaves, and caried on with
 their work. But one of the women
 
 listened very carefuly to the song.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 This woman loked up into the tre. 
 When she saw the girl and the pieces of 
 
 colourful blanket, she cried, “Simbegwire, 
 my brother’s child!” 
 
 
 The other women stoped washing and 
 helped Simbegwire to climb down from 
 
 the tre. Her aunt huged the litle girl 
 and tried to comfort her. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Simbegwire's aunt tok the child to her
 own house. She gave Simbegwire warm
 fod, and tucked her in bed with her
 
 mother’s blanket. 
 
 That night, Simbegwire cried as she went
 
 to slep. But they were tears of relief.
 She knew her aunt would lok after her.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When Simbegwire's father returned 
 home, he found her rom empty. "What 
 
 hapened, Anita?" he asked with a heavy 
 heart. The woman explained that 
 Simbegwire had run away. "I wanted her 
 
 to respect me," she said. "But perhaps I 
 was to strict." 
 
 
 Simbegwire's father left the house and 
 went in the direction of the stream. He 
 
 continued to his sister’s vilage to find 
 out if she has sen Simbegwire. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Simbegwire was playing with her cousins
 when she saw her father from far away.
 
 She was scared he might be angry, so
 she ran inside the house to hide.
 
 
 But her father went to her and said,
 “Simbegwire, you have found a perfect
 
 mother for yourself. One who loves you
 and understands you. I am proud of you
 
 and I love you.” 
 
 They agred that Simbegwire would stay
 
 with her aunt as long as she wanted to.
 
 
 
 
 
 14  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Her father visited her every day. 
 Eventualy, he came with Anita. She 
 
 reached out for Simbegwire's hand. "I'm 
 so sory litle one, I was wrong," she 
 cried. "Wil you let me try again?" 
 
 
 Simbegwire loked at her father and his 
 
 woried face. Then she steped forward 
 slowly and put her arms around Anita. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 15  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The next wek, Anita invited Simbegwire,
 with her cousins and aunt, to the house
 
 for a meal. What a feast! Anita prepared
 al of Simbegwire's favourite fods, and
 everyone ate until they were ful. Then
 
 the children played while the adults
 talked. 
 
 
 Simbegwire felt hapy and brave. She
 decided that son, very son, she would
 
 return home to live with her father and
 her stepmother.
